channel.title: I can use my iPhone, but I can't open jars
channel.description:
The North Denver News reports that Thomas Martel, 28, of Bonnie Brae, Colorado recently underwent “whittling” thumb surgery to better enable him to use the iPhone. Thomas Martel, 28, of Bonnie Brae is a big guy. So he has a hard time using the features on ever-shrinking user interfaces on devices like his new iPhone. At least, he did, until he had his thumbs surgically altered in a revolutionary new surgical technique known as “whittling.” “From my old Treo, to my Blackberry, to this new iPhone, I had a hard time hitting the right buttons, and I always lost those little styluses,” Martel tells reporter James Bently. “Sure, the procedure was expensive, but when I think of all the time I save by being able to use modern handhelds so much faster, I really think the surgery will pay for itself in ten to fifteen years. And what it’s saving me in frustration - that’s priceless.” Well OK, Tom. “This is really, on the edge sort of stuff,” explains Dr. Robert Fox Spars, who worked on developing the procedure. “We’re turning plastic surgery from something that people use in service of vanity, to a real tool for improving workplace efficiency.” As Bently describes it, “the procedure involved making a small incision into both thumbs and shaving down the bones, followed by careful muscular alteration and modification of the fingernails. While Martel’s new thumbs now appear small and effeminate in comparison to his otherwise very large hands, he says he can still lift “pretty much anything I could lift before the surgery - though opening spaghetti sauce jars has been a problem. That was a big surprise.” So now, Martel feels iPhone empowered. But he’s not the only one to struggle with opening spaghetti sauce jars. Push down and twist? Yea, right.
[url=http://blogs.zdnet.com/ip-telephony/?p=2182]From here[/url] I lol'd so bad at this one. "Oh I can use the new electronics now but I struggle with my spaghetti sauce" What the hell is this world coming to?

item.title: I can use my iPhone, but I can't open jars
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“pko, post:8, topic:132300”][quote author=The Un-Named link=topic=183270.msg1666534#msg1666534 date=1186839328]

What the hell is this world coming to?

iWorld. For Mac OS/X.
[/quote]

Theres also RealLives for Win 2k/XP/Vista[/quote]

NoLife for *nix, ofc.

Read full topic

item.title: I can use my iPhone, but I can't open jars
item.dc:creator: @exe626 exe626
item.description:
@exe626 wrote:

Lol, the world of electronics are becoming too efficient for fat people, so they get their fingers shrunk?? I continue to lol.

[quote=“BurnInSilence, post:7, topic:132300”]how much is a iPhone?[/quote]I thought they where 600-800? I was thinking about looking into them and seeing if I would like having it

item.title: I can use my iPhone, but I can't open jars
item.dc:creator: @deoxys505 deoxys505
item.description:
@deoxys505 wrote:

BurnInSilence:

thats a funny coincedence because the other day my friend got a good deal on 2 apple laptops and he likes em so much, he rubbed them and said “Mac O S SEX” which creeped me out badly… and how much is a iPhone?

lol

~$600 sadly

therealjdb:

What the hell is this world coming to?

IDK i think at&t/Cingular is getting lazy

I have a black sony ericson w810i only 3 months old and on the back is/was an orange piece that covers the antennae. I let my brother borrow it and the piece fell off when he had it and we can’t find the piece. I called the cingular warranty dept. and they are sending me a brand new phone because that one $0.50 piece is missing. whats up w/ that???

P.S. I’m not complaining

item.title: I can use my iPhone, but I can't open jars
item.dc:creator: @fellixombc fellixombc
item.description:
@fellixombc wrote:

[quote=“therealjdb, post:1, topic:132300”][quote]
The North Denver News reports that Thomas Martel, 28, of Bonnie Brae, Colorado recently underwent “whittling” thumb surgery to better enable him to use the iPhone.

Thomas Martel, 28, of Bonnie Brae is a big guy. So he has a hard time using the features on ever-shrinking user interfaces on devices like his new iPhone. At least, he did, until he had his thumbs surgically altered in a revolutionary new surgical technique known as “whittling.”

“From my old Treo, to my Blackberry, to this new iPhone, I had a hard time hitting the right buttons, and I always lost those little styluses,” Martel tells reporter James Bently. “Sure, the procedure was expensive, but when I think of all the time I save by being able to use modern handhelds so much faster, I really think the surgery will pay for itself in ten to fifteen years. And what it’s saving me in frustration - that’s priceless.”

Well OK, Tom.

“This is really, on the edge sort of stuff,” explains Dr. Robert Fox Spars, who worked on developing the procedure. “We’re turning plastic surgery from something that people use in service of vanity, to a real tool for improving workplace efficiency.”

As Bently describes it, “the procedure involved making a small incision into both thumbs and shaving down the bones, followed by careful muscular alteration and modification of the fingernails.

While Martel’s new thumbs now appear small and effeminate in comparison to his otherwise very large hands, he says he can still lift “pretty much anything I could lift before the surgery - though opening spaghetti sauce jars has been a problem. That was a big surprise.”

So now, Martel feels iPhone empowered.

But he’s not the only one to struggle with opening spaghetti sauce jars. Push down and twist? Yea, right.[/quote]

From here

I lol’d so bad at this one.

“Oh I can use the new electronics now but I struggle with my spaghetti sauce”
What the hell is this world coming to?[/quote]
i live in colorado 0.0

Read full topic
